snippet: Takoma Park, Md., allowed a library to keep computers mistakenly ordered from a nuclear-connected company because the alternative would have been too costly.
abstract: Enforcing nuclear-free measures has grown more difficult for cities across the nation, since the government imposed stricter rules on disclosing the details of military contracts after the September 11, 2001, terrorist attacks; as local governments face fiscal pressures, it becomes harder to justify spending more money to avoid dealing with companies that have ties to the nation's nuclear weapons program.
lead_paragraph: Takoma Park, Md., allowed a library to keep computers mistakenly ordered from a nuclear-connected company because the alternative would have been too costly.

headline.main: Sometimes Fiscal Urgency Tops Desire to be ‘Nuclear Free,’ Cities Find
headline.print_headline: Sometimes Fiscal Urgency Tops Desire to be ‘Nuclear Free,’ Cities Find
